L1.brief_rationale: Foundational umbrella term covering physical, cognitive, and social growth from birth through adolescence; essential starting point for any student of developmental psychology.
The biological transition to sexual maturity marking the onset of adolescence; widely recognized and central to understanding adolescent development.
The debate over relative contributions of genetics and environment to development; a defining framing question of the entire field.
The developmental stage between childhood and adulthood involving rapid physical, cognitive, and social change; a core life-span concept.
The process of biological and psychological change across adulthood and into old age; essential for lifespan developmental perspectives.
The emotional bond between infant and caregiver; one of the most recognizable concepts in developmental psychology at any level of training.
The growth of thinking, reasoning, and problem-solving across the lifespan; a core domain within developmental psychology.
How children learn to understand and produce language; a high-profile topic connecting developmental psychology to linguistics and neuroscience.
The process by which individuals learn norms, values, and roles from their social environment; a foundational concept in social and developmental psychology.
Innate, biologically-based individual differences in reactivity and self-regulation observable from infancy; commonly discussed in popular and academic contexts.
Physical and neurological growth from conception to birth; a universally taught starting point for lifespan development courses.
Spontaneous activity central to children's physical, social, and cognitive development; recognized across cultures as a hallmark of childhood.
The process of forming a coherent sense of self across adolescence and young adulthood; a widely discussed topic in developmental and personality psychology.

L2.brief_rationale: The canonical four-stage model (sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, formal operational) taught in virtually every introductory developmental psychology course.
Bowlby and Ainsworth's framework explaining how early caregiver bonds shape emotional and social development; a cornerstone theory students are expected to know.
A time-limited window during which specific experiences are necessary for normal development; widely used to explain language acquisition and sensory development.
Vygotsky's concept of the gap between what a learner can do alone and with guidance; standard vocabulary for students of developmental and educational psychology.
The understanding that objects continue to exist when out of sight; a key milestone in Piaget's sensorimotor stage known to most psychology students.
The attachment pattern characterized by confidence in caregiver availability; a fundamental classification from Ainsworth's Strange Situation procedure.
Temporary support provided by a more skilled partner to help a learner accomplish tasks beyond current independent ability; a core Vygotskian concept in education and development.
The process by which children develop ethical reasoning and behavior; associated with Piaget, Kohlberg, and Gilligan and taught at the student level.
The ability to attribute mental states to oneself and others; a landmark cognitive milestone typically emerging around age 4 and central to developmental psychology curricula.

L2.concept: Erik Erikson's stages of psychosocial development
L2.brief_rationale: An eight-stage lifespan model linking psychosocial crises to development from infancy through old age; a standard framework for students studying personality and lifespan psychology.
Ainsworth's laboratory procedure for classifying infant attachment patterns; a foundational experimental paradigm that all developmental psychology students learn.
How children acquire gender identity, roles, and schemas; a prominent topic in developmental psychology spanning biological, cognitive, and social explanations.

Structural and functional brain changes during adolescence including prefrontal cortex maturation and heightened reward sensitivity; increasingly central to student-level understanding of adolescence.

L3.brief_rationale: Applying Vygotsky's ZPD requires understanding how to assess the developmental gap and design scaffolded instruction — a practical working-knowledge skill beyond mere definition.
Understanding the trajectory of ToM acquisition — including false-belief tasks, autism-related deficits, and cross-cultural variation — reflects working knowledge beyond the basic concept.

L3.wikipedia_article: Lawrence Kohlberg's stages of moral development
L3.brief_rationale: Detailed knowledge of pre-conventional, conventional, and post-conventional reasoning stages and their empirical bases requires going beyond the student-level label.
Understanding the developmental trajectory of inhibition, working memory, and cognitive flexibility — and their neural substrates — requires applied knowledge of prefrontal development.
Distinguishing sensitive periods from critical periods and understanding their role in language, emotion regulation, and sensory development reflects nuanced working knowledge.
Infants' use of caregiver emotional signals to guide their own behavior in ambiguous situations; requires understanding of early social cognition and emotional development.
The A-not-B error reveals the interaction between motor planning, memory, and developing knowledge systems in infancy; applying this requires working knowledge beyond basic Piagetian stages.
The coordinated attention of two individuals to the same object or event; a key early social-cognitive milestone that bridges language acquisition, theory of mind, and autism research.
How children construct a coherent personal narrative across time, including childhood amnesia and the role of language; requires working knowledge of memory systems and self-development.
A multi-level framework (microsystem through chronosystem) for understanding how nested environmental contexts shape development; applying it requires integrative working knowledge.
Understanding how infants and children acquire strategies to modulate emotional states, and the role of caregivers and prefrontal maturation, requires working knowledge of affective development.
The role of peer interactions in socializing norms, self-concept, and cognitive skills across childhood and adolescence; applying this requires integrating social learning and attachment frameworks.

L4.brief_rationale: A framework treating development as emergent from the nonlinear interaction of multiple subsystems over time; requires expert understanding of complex systems and their application to developmental phenomena.
Mechanisms by which gene expression is modified by experience and environment (e.g., methylation, histone modification) and how these changes shape developmental trajectories across generations.

Spelke's proposal that infants are born with domain-specific systems for representing objects, agents, numbers, and geometry; requires deep engagement with nativist-empiricist debates and infant cognition research.

Belsky's proposal that certain individuals are more reactive to both adverse and supportive environments due to biological sensitivity; an expert-level refinement of gene-environment interaction models.

Distinguishing experience-expectant from experience-dependent plasticity and understanding how neural circuits are shaped by environmental input during development requires integration of neuroscience and developmental theory.

The mechanism by which infants extract distributional regularities from linguistic input to bootstrap phoneme and word boundaries; requires expert knowledge of computational and developmental psycholinguistics.

The process by which a parent's own attachment representation — assessed via the Adult Attachment Interview — predicts their infant's attachment classification; requires expert-level knowledge of attachment measurement and transmission mechanisms.

The process by which organisms modify their own developmental environments, creating feedback loops between genes, behavior, and culture; an advanced theoretical framework drawing on evolutionary developmental psychology.

The Barker hypothesis and related evidence that prenatal nutritional and stress exposures permanently alter physiological and behavioral set points — reflecting expert knowledge at the intersection of obstetrics, epidemiology, and developmental psychology.

A contemporary metatheoretical framework emphasizing bidirectional, multilevel relations among biological, psychological, and social systems across the lifespan; associated with Lerner and representing the current leading edge of lifespan theory.

Models (e.g., Steinberg's imbalance model) positing that adolescent risk-taking reflects an early-maturing socioemotional system outpacing a later-maturing cognitive control system; requires expert synthesis of neuroscience and behavioral development.

Children's tendency to interpret natural phenomena and artifacts in terms of goals and purposes (Keleman's research); an expert-level topic at the intersection of cognitive development, intuitive biology, and the origins of religious cognition.
